description: From Middle English blosme, from Old English blostm, blostma, from Proto-Germanic *blōsmaz (compare West Frisian blossem, Dutch bloesem), an enlargement of *blōstaz (compare German Blust), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰleh₃-s- (“bloom, flower”), from *bʰleh₃- (“to bloom, to thrive”). Cognate with Albanian bleron (“to blossom, to thrive”), Latin flōs (“flower”), Flōra (“goddess of plants”). See more at blow (etymology 4).

entries.meaning: A flower, especially one indicating that a fruit tree is fruiting; (collectively) a mass of such flowers.
examples: The blossom has come early this year.

entries.meaning: The state or season of producing such flowers.
(figurative) A blooming period or stage of development; something lovely that gives rich promise.
The colour of a horse that has white hairs intermixed with sorrel and bay hairs.

verbs.description: blossom (third-person singular simple present blossoms, present participle blossoming, simple past and past participle blossomed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have, or open into, blossoms; to bloom.
(intransitive) To begin to thrive or flourish.
